About the module

Topics covered
The MATH38161 module is designed to run over the course of 11 weeks. It has six parts, each covering a particular aspect of multivariate statistics and machine learning:

Multivariate random variables and estimation in large and small sample settings (W1 and W2)
Transformations and dimension reduction (W3 and W4)
Unsupervised learning/clustering (W5 and W6)
Supervised learning/classification (W7 and W8)
Measuring and modelling multivariate dependencies (W9)
Nonlinear and nonparametric models (W10, W11)

This module focuses on:

Concepts and methods (not on theory)
Implementation and application in R
Practical data analysis and interpretation (incl. report writing)
Modern tools in data science and statistics (R markdown, R studio)



Additional support material
If you are a University of Manchester student and enrolled in this module you will find on Blackboard:

a weekly learning plan for an 11 week study period,
weekly worksheets with with examples (theory and application in R) and solutions in R Markdown, and
exam papers of previous years.

Furthermore, there is also an MATH38161 online reading list hosted by the University of Manchester library.

text: 1.1 Essentials in multivariate statistics

title: 1  Multivariate random variables
text:
Why multivariate statistics?
In science we use experiments to learn about underlying mechanisms of interest, both deterministic and stochastic, to compare different models and to verify or reject hypotheses about the world. Statistics provides tools to quantify this procedure and offers methods to link data (experiments) with probabilistic models (hypotheses).
In univariate statistics with we use relatively simple approaches based on a single random variable or single parameter. However, in practise we often have to consider multiple random variables and multiple parameters, so we need more complex models and also be able to deal with more complex data. Hence, the need for multivariate statistical approaches and models.
Specifically, multivariate statistics is concerned with methods and models for random vectors and random matrices, rather than just random univariate (scalar) variables. Therefore, in multivariate statistics we will frequently make use of matrix notation.
Closely related to multivariate statistics (traditionally a subfield of statistics) is machine learning (ML) which is traditionally a subfield of computer science. ML used to focus more on algorithms rather on probabilistic modelling but nowadays most machine learning methods are fully based on statistical multivariate approaches, so the two fields are converging.
Multivariate models provide a means to learn dependencies and interactions among the components of the random variables which in turn allow us to draw conclusion about underlying mechanisms of interest (e.g. in biological or medical problems).
Two main tasks:

unsupervised learning (finding structure, clustering)
supervised learning (training from labelled data, followed by prediction)

Challenges:

complexity of model needs to be appropriate for problem and available data
high dimensions make estimation and inference difficult
computational issues



Univariate vs. multivariate random variables
Univariate random variable (dimension \(d=1\)): \[x \sim F\] where \(x\) is a scalar and \(F\) is the distribution. \(\text{E}(x) = \mu\) denotes the mean and \(\text{Var}(x) = \sigma^2\) the variance of \(x\).
Multivariate random vector of dimension \(d\): \[\symbfit x= (x_1, x_2,...,x_d)^T  \sim F\]
\(\symbfit x\) is vector valued random variable.
The vector \(\symbfit x\) is column vector (=matrix of size \(d \times 1\)). Its components \(x_1, x_2,...,x_d\) are univariate random variables. The dimension \(d\) is also often denoted by \(p\) or \(q\).
Note that for simplicity of notation we use the same symbol to denote the random variable and its elementary outcomes (in particular we don’t use capitalisation to indicate a random variable). This convention greatly facilitates working with random vectors and matrices and follows, e.g., the classic multivariate statistics textbook by Mardia, Kent, and Bibby (1979). If a quantity is random we will always specify this explicitly in the context.


Multivariate data
Vector notation:
Samples from a multivariate distribution are vectors (not scalars as for univariate normal): \[\symbfit x_1,\symbfit x_2,...,\symbfit x_n \stackrel{\text{iid}}\sim F\]
Matrix and component notation:
All the data points are commonly collected into a matrix \(\symbfit X\).
In statistics the convention is to store each data vector in the rows of the data matrix \(\symbfit X\):
\[\symbfit X= (\symbfit x_1,\symbfit x_2,...,\symbfit x_n)^T = \begin{pmatrix}
    x_{11}  & x_{12} & \dots & x_{1d}   \\
    x_{21}  & x_{22} & \dots & x_{2d}   \\
    \vdots \\
    x_{n1}  & x_{n2} & \dots & x_{nd}
\end{pmatrix}\]
Therefore, \[\symbfit x_1=\begin{pmatrix}
    x_{11}       \\
    \vdots \\
    x_{1d}
\end{pmatrix} , \space \symbfit x_2=\begin{pmatrix}
    x_{21}       \\
    \vdots \\
    x_{2d}
\end{pmatrix} , \ldots , \symbfit x_n=\begin{pmatrix}
    x_{n1}       \\
    \vdots \\
    x_{nd}
\end{pmatrix}\]
Thus, in statistics the first index runs over \((1,...,n)\) and denotes the samples while the second index runs over \((1,...,d)\) and refers to the variables.
The statistics convention on data matrices is not universal! In fact, in most of the machine learning literature in engineering and computer science the data samples are stored in the columns so that the variables appear in the rows (thus in the engineering convention the data matrix is transposed compared to the statistics convention).
In order to avoid confusion and ambiguity it is recommended to prefer vector notation to describe data over matrix or component notation (see also the section below on estimating covariance matrices for examples).


Mean of a random vector
The mean / expectation of a random vector with dimensions \(d\) is also a vector with dimensions \(d\): \[\text{E}(\symbfit x) = \symbfit \mu= \begin{pmatrix}
    \text{E}(x_1)       \\
    \text{E}(x_2)       \\
    \vdots \\
    \text{E}(x_d)
\end{pmatrix} = \left( \begin{array}{l}
    \mu_1       \\
    \mu_2       \\
    \vdots \\
    \mu_d
\end{array}\right)\]


Variance of a random vector
Recall the definition of mean and variance for a univariate random variable:
\[\text{E}(x) = \mu\]
\[\text{Var}(x) = \sigma^2 = \text{E}( (x-\mu)^2 )=\text{E}( (x-\mu)(x-\mu) ) = \text{E}(x^2)-\mu^2\]
Definition of variance of a random vector:
\[\text{Var}(\symbfit x) = \underbrace{\symbfit \Sigma}_{d\times d} =
\text{E}\left(\underbrace{(\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)}_{d\times 1} \underbrace{(\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T}_{1\times d} \right)
= \text{E}(\symbfit x\symbfit x^T)-\symbfit \mu\symbfit \mu^T\]
The variance of a random vector is, therefore, not a vector but a matrix!
\[\symbfit \Sigma= (\sigma_{ij}) = \underbrace{\begin{pmatrix}
    \sigma_{11} & \dots & \sigma_{1d}\\
     \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
    \sigma_{d1} & \dots & \sigma_{dd}
\end{pmatrix}}_{d\times d}\]


Properties of the covariance matrix

\(\symbfit \Sigma\) is real valued: \(\sigma_{ij} \in \mathbb{R}\)
\(\symbfit \Sigma\) is symmetric: \(\sigma_{ij} = \sigma_{ji}\)
The diagonal of \(\symbfit \Sigma\) contains \(\sigma_{ii} = \text{Var}(x_i) = \sigma_i^2\), i.e. the variances of the components of \(\symbfit x\).
Off-diagonal elements \(\sigma_{ij} = \text{Cov}(x_i,x_j)\) represent linear dependencies among the \(x_i\). \(\Longrightarrow\) linear regression, correlation

How many distinct elements does \(\symbfit \Sigma\) have? \[
\frac{d(d+1)}{2}
\] This grows with the square of the dimension \(d\), i.e. it grows with order \(O(d^2)\) (Table 1.1).
For large dimension \(d\) the covariance matrix has many components!
–> computationally expensive (both for storage and in handling) –> very challenging to estimate \(\symbfit \Sigma\) in high dimensions \(d\).
Note: matrix inversion requires \(O(d^3)\) operations using standard algorithms such as Gauss Jordan elimination. 1 Hence, computing \(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\) is computationally expensive for large \(d\)!


Eigenvalue decomposition of \(\symbfit \Sigma\)
Recall from linear matrix algebra that any real symmetric matrix has real eigenvalues and a complete set of orthogonal eigenvectors. These can be obtained by orthogonal eigendecomposition. 2
Applying eigenvalue decomposition to the covariance matrix yields \[
\symbfit \Sigma= \symbfit U\symbfit \Lambda\symbfit U^T
\] where \(\symbfit U\) is an orthogonal matrix 3 containing the eigenvectors of the covariance matrix and \[\symbfit \Lambda= \begin{pmatrix}
    \lambda_{1} & \dots & 0\\
     \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
    0 & \dots & \lambda_{d}
\end{pmatrix}\] contains the corresponding eigenvalues \(\lambda_i\).
Importantly, the eigenvalues of a covariance matrix are not only real-valued but are by construction further constrained to be non-negative. This can be seen by computing the quadratic form \(\symbfit z^T  \symbfit \Sigma\symbfit z\) where \(\symbfit z\) is a non-random vector. For any non-zero \(\symbfit z\) \[
\begin{split}
\symbfit z^T  \symbfit \Sigma\symbfit z& = \symbfit z^T \text{E}\left(  (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu) (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T  \right) \symbfit z\\
& =  \text{E}\left( \symbfit z^T (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu) (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T \symbfit z\right) \\
& =  \text{E}\left( \left( \symbfit z^T (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu) \right)^2 \right) \geq 0 \, .\\
\end{split}
\] Furthermore, with \(\symbfit y= \symbfit U^T \symbfit z\) we get \[
\begin{split}
\symbfit z^T  \symbfit \Sigma\symbfit z& =  \symbfit z^T\symbfit U\symbfit \Lambda\symbfit U^T \symbfit z\\
                      & =  \symbfit y^T \symbfit \Lambda\symbfit y= \sum_{i=1}^d  y_i^2 \lambda_i \\
\end{split}
\] and hence all the \(\lambda_i \geq 0\). Therefore the covariance matrix \(\symbfit \Sigma\) is always positive semi-definite.
In fact, unless there is collinearity ( i.e. a variable is a linear function the other variables) all eigenvalues will be positive and \(\symbfit \Sigma\) is positive definite.


Joint covariance matrix
Assume we have random vector \(\symbfit z\) with mean \(\text{E}(\symbfit z) = \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit z}\) and covariance matrix \(\text{Var}(\symbfit z) = \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit z}\).
Often it makes sense to partion the components of \(\symbfit z\) into two groups \[
\symbfit z= \begin{pmatrix} \symbfit x\\ \symbfit y\end{pmatrix}
\] This induces a corresponding partition in the expectation \[
\symbfit \mu_{\symbfit z} =  \begin{pmatrix} \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit x} \\ \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit y} \end{pmatrix}
\] where \(\text{E}(\symbfit x) = \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit x}\) and \(\text{E}(\symbfit y) = \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit y}\).
Furthermore, the joint covariance matrix for \(\symbfit x\) and \(\symbfit y\) can then be written as \[
\symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit z} =
\begin{pmatrix}
\symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x} &  \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x\symbfit y} \\
\symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit y\symbfit x} & \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit y} \\
\end{pmatrix}
\] It contains the within-group group covariance matrices \(\symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x}\) and \(\symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit y}\) as diagonal elements and the cross-covariance matrix \(\symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x\symbfit y} = \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit y\symbfit x}^T\) as off-diagonal element.
Note that the cross-covariance matrix \(\symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x\symbfit y}\) is rectangular and not symmetric. We also write \(\text{Cov}(\symbfit x, \symbfit y) = \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x\symbfit y}\) and we can define cross-covariance directly by \[
\text{Cov}(\symbfit x, \symbfit y) = \text{E}\left( (\symbfit x- \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit x}) ( \symbfit y- \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit y} )^T \right) = \text{E}(\symbfit x\symbfit y^T)-\symbfit \mu_{\symbfit x} \symbfit \mu_{\symbfit y}^T
\]


Quantities related to the covariance matrix

Correlation matrix \(\symbfit P\)
The correlation matrix \(\symbfit P\) (= upper case greek “rho”) is the standardised covariance matrix
\[\rho_{ij} = \frac{\sigma_{ij}}{\sqrt{\sigma_{ii}\sigma_{jj}}}=\text{Cor}(x_i,x_j)\]
\[\rho_{ii} = 1 = \text{Cor}(x_i,x_i)\]
\[ \symbfit P= (\rho_{ij}) = \begin{pmatrix}
    1 & \dots & \rho_{1d}\\
     \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
    \rho_{d1} & \dots & 1
\end{pmatrix}\]
where \(\symbfit P\) (“upper case rho”) is a symmetric matrix (\(\rho_{ij}=\rho_{ji}\)).
Note the variance-correlation decomposition
\[\symbfit \Sigma= \symbfit V^{\frac{1}{2}} \symbfit P\symbfit V^{\frac{1}{2}}\]
where \(\symbfit V\) is a diagonal matrix containing the variances:
\[ \symbfit V= \begin{pmatrix}
    \sigma_{11} & \dots & 0\\
     \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
    0 & \dots & \sigma_{dd}
\end{pmatrix}\]
\[\symbfit P= \symbfit V^{-\frac{1}{2}}\symbfit \Sigma\symbfit V^{-\frac{1}{2}}\]
This is the definition of correlation written in matrix notation.
As with the covariance matrix, in many applications it makes sense to partition a joint correlation matrix \[
\symbfit P_{\symbfit z} =
\begin{pmatrix}
\symbfit P_{\symbfit x} &  \symbfit P_{\symbfit x\symbfit y} \\
\symbfit P_{\symbfit y\symbfit x} & \symbfit P_{\symbfit y} \\
\end{pmatrix}
\] into within-group group correlation matrices \[
\symbfit P_{\symbfit x} = \symbfit V_{\symbfit x}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x} \symbfit V_{\symbfit x}^{-\frac{1}{2}}
\] and \[
\symbfit P_{\symbfit y} = \symbfit V_{\symbfit y}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit y} \symbfit V_{\symbfit y}^{-\frac{1}{2}}
\] and the cross-correlation matrix \[
\symbfit P_{\symbfit x\symbfit y} = \symbfit V_{\symbfit x}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit x\symbfit y} \symbfit V_{\symbfit y}^{-\frac{1}{2}}
\] with \[
\symbfit P_{\symbfit y\symbfit x} = \symbfit P_{\symbfit x\symbfit y}^T
= \symbfit V_{\symbfit y}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \symbfit \Sigma_{\symbfit y\symbfit x} \symbfit V_{\symbfit x}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \,.
\]


Precision matrix or concentration matrix
\[\symbfit \Omega= (\omega_{ij}) = \symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\]
\(\symbfit \Omega\) (“Omega”) is the inverse of the covariance matrix.
The inverse of the covariance matrix can be obtained via the spectral decomposition, followed by inverting the eigenvalues \(\lambda_i\): \[\symbfit \Sigma^{-1} = \symbfit U\symbfit \Lambda^{-1} \symbfit U^T =
\symbfit U\begin{pmatrix}
    \lambda_{1}^{-1} & \dots & 0\\
     \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
    0 & \dots & \lambda_{d}^{-1}
\end{pmatrix} \symbfit U^T \]
Note that all eigenvalues \(\lambda_i\) need to be positive so that \(\symbfit \Sigma\) can be inverted. (i.e., \(\symbfit \Sigma\) needs to be positive definite).
If any \(\lambda_i = 0\) then \(\symbfit \Sigma\) is singular and not invertible.
Importance of \(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\):

Many expressions in multivariate statistics contain \(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\) and not \(\symbfit \Sigma\).
\(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\) has close connection with graphical models (e.g. conditional independence graph, partial correlations).
\(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\) is a natural parameter from an exponential family perspective.



Partial correlation matrix
This is a standardised version of the precision matrix, see later chapter on graphical models.


Total variation and generalised variance
To summarise the covariance matrix \(\symbfit \Sigma\) in a single scalar value there are two commonly used measures:

total variation: \(\text{Tr}(\symbfit \Sigma) = \sum_{i=1}^d \lambda_i\)
generalised variance: \(\det(\symbfit \Sigma) = \prod_{i=1}^d \lambda_i\)

The generalised variance \(\det(\symbfit \Sigma)\) is also known as the volume of \(\symbfit \Sigma\).

1.2 Multivariate distributions

Common distributions
In multivariate statistics we make use of multivariate distributions. These are typically generalisations of corresponding univariate distribution.
Among the most commonly used multivariate distributions are:

The multivariate normal distribution \(N_d(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma)\) as a generalisation of univariate normal distribution \(N(\mu, \sigma^2)\)
The categorical distribution \(\text{Cat}(\symbfit \pi)\) as a generalisation of the Bernoulli distribution \(\text{Ber}(\theta)\)
The multinomial distribution \(\text{Mult}(n, \symbfit \pi)\) as a generalisation of binomial distribution \(\text{Bin}(n, \theta)\)

The above distribution have already been introduced earlier in MATH27720 Statistics 2.
Conceptually, these multivariate generalisation work behave exactly the same as their univariate counterparts and are employed in the same settings.


Further multivariate distributions
For multivariate Bayesian analyis we also need to consider a number of further multivariate distributions:

The Dirichlet distribution \(\text{Dir}(\symbfit \alpha)\) as the generalisation of the beta distribution \(\text{Beta}(\alpha, \beta)\),
The Wishart distribution as the generalisation of the gamma distribution \(\text{Gam}(\alpha, \theta)\),
The inverse Wishart distribution as the generalisation of the inverse gamma distribution \(\text{Inv-Gam}(\alpha, \beta)\).

For technical details of the densities etc. of the multivariate distribution families we refer to the supplementary Probability and Distribution refresher notes.

title: 1  Multivariate random variables
text:
1.3 Multivariate normal distribution
The multivariate normal disribution is ubiquitous in multivariate statistics and hence it is important to discuss it in more detail.
The multivariate normal model is a generalisation of the univariate normal distribution from dimension 1 to dimension \(d\).

Univariate normal distribution:
\[\text{Dimension } d = 1\] \[x \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\] \[\text{E}(x) = \mu \space , \space  \text{Var}(x) = \sigma^2\]
Probability Density Function:
\[f(x |\mu, \sigma^2) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \exp\left( -\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2} \right) \]
Plot of univariate normal density 








Figure 1.1: Illustration of the density of the normal distribution.





See Figure 1.1. The density is unimodal with a mode at \(\mu\) and width determined by \(\sigma\) (in this plot: \(\mu=2, \sigma^2=1\) )
Special case: standard normal with \(\mu=0\) and \(\sigma^2=1\):
\[f(x |\mu=0,\sigma^2=1)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left( {-\frac{x^2}{2}} \right) \]
Differential entropy:
\[
H(F) = \frac{1}{2} (\log(2 \pi \sigma^2) + 1)
\]
Cross-entropy:
\[
H(F_{\text{ref}}, F) = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{(\mu - \mu_{\text{ref}})^2}{ \sigma^2 }
+\frac{\sigma^2_{\text{ref}}}{\sigma^2}  +\log(2 \pi \sigma^2) \right)
\] KL divergence:
\[
D_{\text{KL}}(F_{\text{ref}}, F) = H(F_{\text{ref}}, F) - H(F_{\text{ref}}) =
\frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{(\mu - \mu_{\text{ref}})^2}{ \sigma^2 }
+\frac{\sigma^2_{\text{ref}}}{\sigma^2}  -\log\left(\frac{\sigma^2_{\text{ref}}}{ \sigma^2}\right) -1
\right)
\]
Maximum entropy characterisation: the normal distribution is the unique distribution that has the highest (differential) entropy over all continuous distributions with support from minus infinity to plus infinity with a given mean and variance.
This is in fact one of the reasons why the normal distribution is so important (und useful) – if we only know that a random variable has a mean and variance, and not much else, then using the normal distribution will be a reasonable and well justified model.


Multivariate normal model
\[\text{Dimension } d\] \[\symbfit x\sim N_d(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma)\] \[\text{E}(\symbfit x) = \symbfit \mu\space , \space  \text{Var}(\symbfit x) = \symbfit \Sigma\]
Density:
\[f(\symbfit x| \symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma) = \det(2 \pi \symbfit \Sigma)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \exp\left({{-\frac{1}{2}} \underbrace{\underbrace{(\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T}_{1 \times d} \underbrace{\symbfit \Sigma^{-1}}_{d \times d} \underbrace{(\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)}_{d \times 1} }_{1 \times 1 = \text{scalar!}}}\right)\]

the density contains the precision matrix \(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\)
to invert the covariance matrix \(\symbfit \Sigma\) we need to invert its eigenvalues \(\lambda_i\) (hence we require that all \(\lambda_i > 0\))
the density also contains \(\det(\symbfit \Sigma) = \prod\limits_{i=1}^d \lambda_i\) \(\equiv\) product of the eigenvalues of \(\symbfit \Sigma\)
note that \(\det(2 \pi \symbfit \Sigma)^{-\frac{1}{2}} = \det(2 \pi \symbfit I_d)^{-\frac{1}{2}} \det(\symbfit \Sigma)^{-\frac{1}{2}} =  (2 \pi)^{-d/2} \det(\symbfit \Sigma)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\)

Special case: standard multivariate normal with \[\symbfit \mu=\symbfup 0, \symbfit \Sigma=\symbfit I=\begin{pmatrix}
    1 & \dots & 0\\
     \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
    0 & \dots & 1
\end{pmatrix}\]
\[f(\symbfit x| \symbfit \mu=\symbfup 0,\symbfit \Sigma=\symbfit I)=(2\pi)^{-d/2}\exp\left( -\frac{1}{2} \symbfit x^T \symbfit x\right) = \prod\limits_{i=1}^d \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\left(-\frac{x_i^2}{2}\right)\] which is equivalent to the product of \(d\) univariate standard normals!
Misc:

for \(d=1\), the multivariate normal density reduces to the univariate normal density.
for \(\symbfit \Sigma\) diagonal (i.e. \(\symbfit P= \symbfit I\), no correlation), the multivariate normal density is the product of univariate normal densities (see Worksheet 2).

Plot of the multivariate normal density:








Figure 1.2: Illustration of the density of the bivariate normal distribution.





Figure 1.2 illustrates the bivariate normal distribution, with location determined by \(\symbfit \mu\), shape determined by \(\symbfit \Sigma\) and a single mode. The support ranges from \(-\infty\) to \(+\infty\) in each dimension.
An interactive R Shiny web app of the bivariate normal density plot is available online at https://minerva.it.manchester.ac.uk/shiny/strimmer/bvn/.
Differential entropy:
\[
H = \frac{1}{2} (\log \det(2 \pi \symbfit \Sigma) + d)
\]
Cross-entropy:
\[
H(F_{\text{ref}}, F) = \frac{1}{2}   \biggl\{
        (\symbfit \mu-\symbfit \mu_{\text{ref}})^T \symbfit \Sigma^{-1} (\symbfit \mu-\symbfit \mu_{\text{ref}})
      + \text{Tr}\biggl(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1} \symbfit \Sigma_{\text{ref}} \biggr)
    + \log \det \biggl( 2 \pi \symbfit \Sigma\biggr)    \biggr\}
\] KL divergence:
\[
\begin{split}
D_{\text{KL}}(F_{\text{ref}}, F) &= H(F_{\text{ref}}, F) - H(F_{\text{ref}}) \\
&= \frac{1}{2}   \biggl\{
        (\symbfit \mu-\symbfit \mu_{\text{ref}})^T \symbfit \Sigma^{-1} (\symbfit \mu-\symbfit \mu_{\text{ref}})
      + \text{Tr}\biggl(\symbfit \Sigma^{-1} \symbfit \Sigma_{\text{ref}} \biggr)
    - \log \det \biggl( \symbfit \Sigma^{-1} \symbfit \Sigma_{\text{ref}} \biggr)
     - d   \biggr\} \\
\end{split}
\]


Shape of the multivariate normal density
Now we show that the contour lines of the multivariate normal density always take on the form of an ellipse, and that the radii and orientation of the ellipse is determined by the eigenvalues of \(\symbfit \Sigma\).
We start by observing that a circle with radius \(r\) around the origin can be described as the set of points \((x_1,x_2)\) satisfying \(x_1^2+x_2^2 = r^2\), or equivalently, \(\frac{x_1^2}{r^2} + \frac{x_2^2}{r^2} = 1\). This is generalised to the shape of an ellipse by allowing (in two dimensions) for two radii \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) with \(\frac{x_1^2}{r_1^2} + \frac{x_2^2}{r_2^2} = 1\), or in vector notation \(\symbfit x^T \text{Diag}(r_1^2, r_2^2)^{-1} \symbfit x= 1\). Here two axes of the ellipse are parallel to the two coordinate axes.
In \(d\) dimensions and allowing for rotation of the axes and a shift of the origin from 0 to \(\symbfit \mu\) the condition for an ellipse is \[(\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T \symbfit Q\, \text{Diag}(r_1^2, \ldots , r_d^2)^{-1} \symbfit Q^T (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu) = 1\] where \(\symbfit Q\) is an orthogonal matrix whose column vectors indicate the direction of the axes. These are also called the principal axes of the ellipse, and by construction all \(d\) principal axes are perpendicular to each other.
A contour line of a probability density function is a set of connected points where the density assumes the same constant value. In the case of the multivariate normal distribution keeping the density \(f(\symbfit x| \symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma)\) at some fixed value implies that \((\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T \symbfit \Sigma^{-1} (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu) = c\) where \(c\) is a constant. Using the eigenvalue decomposition of \(\symbfit \Sigma= \symbfit U\symbfit \Lambda\symbfit U^T\) we can rewrite this condition as \[
(\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T \symbfit U\symbfit \Lambda^{-1} \symbfit U^T (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu) = c \,.
\] This implies that

the contour lines of the multivariate normal density are indeed ellipses,
the direction of the principal axes of the ellipse are given correspond to the colum vectors in \(\symbfit U\) (i.e. the eigenvectors of \(\symbfit \Sigma\)), and
the squared radii of the ellipse are proportional to the eigenvalues of \(\symbfit \Sigma\) Equivalently, the positive square roots of the eigenvalues are proportional to the radii of the ellipse. Hence, for a singular covariance matrix with one or more \(\lambda_i=0\) the corresponding radii are zero.

An interactive R Shiny web app to play with the contour lines of the bivariate normal distribution is available online at https://minerva.it.manchester.ac.uk/shiny/strimmer/bvn/.


Three types of covariances
Following the above we can parameterise a covariance matrix in terms of its i) volume, ii) shape and iii) orientation by writing \[
\symbfit \Sigma= \kappa \, \symbfit U\symbfit A\symbfit U^T = \symbfit U\; \left(\kappa \symbfit A\right) \; \symbfit U^T
\] with \(\symbfit A=\text{Diag}(a_1, \ldots, a_d)\) and \(\det(\symbfit A) = \prod_{i=1}^d a_i = 1\). Note that in this parameterisation the eigenvalues of \(\symbfit \Sigma\) are \(\lambda_i = \kappa a_i\).

The volume is \(\det(\symbfit \Sigma) = \kappa^d\), determined by a single parameter \(\kappa\). This parameter can be interpreted as the length of the side of a \(d\)-dimensional hypercube.
The shape is determined by the diagonal matrix \(\symbfit A\) with \(d-1\) free parameters. Note that there are only \(d-1\) and not \(d\) free parameters because of the constraint \(\det(\symbfit A) = 1\).
The orientation is given by the orthogonal matrix \(\symbfit U\), with \(d (d-1)/2\) free parameters.

This leads to classification of covariances into three varieties:
Type 1: spherical covariance \(\symbfit \Sigma=\kappa \symbfit I\), with spherical contour lines, 1 free parameter (\(\symbfit A=\symbfit I\), \(\symbfit U=\symbfit I\)).
Example (Figure 1.3): \(\symbfit \Sigma= \begin{pmatrix}
2 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{pmatrix}\) with \(\sqrt{\lambda_1/ \lambda_2} = 1\):








Figure 1.3: Contor lines for a spherical covariance matrix.





Type 2: diagonal covariance \(\symbfit \Sigma= \kappa \symbfit A\), with elliptical contour lines and the principal axes of the ellipse oriented parallel to the coordinate axes, \(d\) free parameters (\(\symbfit U=\symbfit I\)).
Example (Figure 1.4): \(\symbfit \Sigma= \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{pmatrix}\) with \(\sqrt{\lambda_1 / \lambda_2} \approx 1.41\):








Figure 1.4: Contour lines for a diagonal covariance matrix.





Type 3: general unrestricted covariance \(\symbfit \Sigma\), with elliptical contour lines, with the principal axes of the ellipse oriented according to the column vectors in \(\symbfit U\), \(d (d+1)/2\) free parameters.
Example (Figure 1.5): \(\symbfit \Sigma= \begin{pmatrix}
2 & 0.6 \\
0.6 & 1
\end{pmatrix}\) with \(\sqrt{\lambda_1 / \lambda_2} \approx 2.20\):








Figure 1.5: Contour lines for a general covariance matrix.







Concentration of probability mass for small and large dimension
The density of the multivariate normal distribution has a bell shape with a single mode. Intuitively, we may assume that most of the probability mass is always concentrated around this mode, as it is in the univariate case (\(d=1\)). While this is still true for small dimensions (small \(d\)) we now show that this intuition is incorrect for high dimensions (large \(d\)).
For simplicity we consider the standard multivariate normal distribution with dimension \(d\) \[\symbfit x\sim N_d(\symbfup 0, \symbfit I_d)\] with a spherical covariance \(\symbfit I_d\) and sample \(\symbfit x\). The squared Euclidean length of \(\symbfit x\) is \(r^2= || \symbfit x||^2 = \symbfit x^T \symbfit x= \sum_{i=1}^d x_i^2\). The corresponding density of the \(d\)-dimensional standard multivariate normal distribution is \[
g_d(\symbfit x) = (2\pi)^{-d/2} e^{-\symbfit x^T \symbfit x/2}
\] A natural way to define the main part of the “bell” of the standard multivariate normal as the set of all \(\symbfit x\) for which the density is larger than a specified fraction \(\eta\) (say 0.001) of the maximum value of the density \(g_d(0)\) at the peak at zero. To formalise \[
B = \left\{ \symbfit x: \frac{g_d(\symbfit x)}{ g_d(0)} > \eta    \right\}
\] which can be equivalently written as the set \[
B = \{ \symbfit x: \symbfit x^T \symbfit x= r^2 < -2 \log(\eta) = r^2_{\max} \}
\]
Each individual component in the sample \(\symbfit x\) is independently distributed as \(x_i \sim N(0,1)\), hence \(r^2 \sim \text{$\chi^2_{d}$}\) is chi-squared distributed with degree of freedom \(d\). The probability \(\text{Pr}(\symbfit x\in B)\) can thus be obtained as the value of the cumulative density function of a chi-squared distribution with \(d\) degrees of freedom at \(r^2_{\max}\). Computing this probability for fixed \(\eta\) as a function of the dimension \(d\) we obtain the curve shown in Figure 1.6. In this plot we have used \(\eta=0.001\). You can see that for dimensions up to around \(d=10\) the probability mass is indeed concentrated in the center of the distribution but from \(d=30\) onwards it has moved completely to the tails.








Figure 1.6: Concentration of probability mass in the center of a multivariate normal distribution.









Mardia, K. V., J. T. Kent, and J. M. Bibby. 1979. Multivariate Analysis. Academic Press.

title: 2  Multivariate estimation
text:
2.1 Overview
In practical application of multivariate normal model we need to learn its parameters from observed data points:
\[\symbfit x_1,\symbfit x_2,...,\symbfit x_n \stackrel{\text{iid}}\sim F_{\symbfit \theta}\]
We first consider the case when there are many measurements available (\(n\) large), and then subsequently the case when the number of data points \(n\) is small compared to the dimensions and the number of parameters.
In a previous course in year 2 (see MATH27720 Statistics 2) the method of maximum likelihood as well as the essentials of Bayesian statistics were introduced. Below we apply these approaches to the problem of estimating the parameters of the multivariate normal distribution and also show how the main Bayesian modelling strategies extend to the multivariate case.

title: 2  Multivariate estimation
text:
2.2 Empirical estimates

General principle
For large \(n\) we have thanks to the law of large numbers: \[\underbrace{F}_{\text{true}} \approx \underbrace{\widehat{F}_n}_{\text{empirical}}\]
We now would like to estimate \(A\) which is a functional \(A=m(F)\) of the distribution \(F\) — recall that a functional is a function that takes another function as argument. For example all standard distributional summaries such as the mean, the median etc. are derived from \(F\) and hence are functionals of \(F\).
The empirical estimate is obtained by replacing the unknown true distribution \(F\) with the observed empirical distribution: \(\hat{A} = m(\widehat{F}_n)\).
For example, the expectation of a random variable is approximated/estimated as the average over the observations: \[\text{E}_F(\symbfit x) \approx \text{E}_{\widehat{F}_n}(\symbfit x) = \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} \symbfit x_k\] \[\text{E}_F(g(\symbfit x)) \approx  \text{E}_{\widehat{F}_n}(g(\symbfit x)) = \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} g(\symbfit x_k)\]
Simple recipe to obtain an empirical estimator: simply replace the expectation operator by the sample average.
What does this work: the empirical distribution \(\widehat{F}_n\) is the nonparametric maximum likelihood estimate of \(F\) (see below for likelihood estimation).
Note: the approximation of \(F\) by \(\widehat{F}_n\) is also the basis other approaches such as Efron’s bootstrap method (1979) 1.


Empirical estimates of mean and covariance
Recall the definitions: \[
\symbfit \mu= \text{E}(\symbfit x)
\] and \[
\symbfit \Sigma= \text{E}\left(   (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu) (\symbfit x-\symbfit \mu)^T \right)
\]
For the empirical estimate we replace the expectations by the corresponding sample averages.
These resulting estimators can be written in three different ways:
Vector notation:
\[\hat{\symbfit \mu} = \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} \symbfit x_k\]
\[
\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma} = \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} (\symbfit x_k-\hat{\symbfit \mu})  (\symbfit x_k-\hat{\symbfit \mu})^T
= \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} \symbfit x_k  \symbfit x_k^T - \hat{\symbfit \mu} \hat{\symbfit \mu}^T
\]
Component notation:
The corresponding component notation with \(\symbfit X= (x_{ki})\) and following the statistics convention with samples contained in rows of \(\symbfit X\) we get:
\[\hat{\mu}_i = \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} x_{ki}\]
\[\hat{\sigma}_{ij} = \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} (x_{ki}-\hat{\mu}_i) (
x_{kj}-\hat{\mu}_j )\]
\[\hat{\symbfit \mu}=\begin{pmatrix}
    \hat{\mu}_{1}       \\
    \vdots \\
    \hat{\mu}_{d}
\end{pmatrix}, \widehat{\symbfit \Sigma} = (\hat{\sigma}_{ij})\]
Variance estimate:
\[\hat{\sigma}_{ii} = \frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{k=1} \left(x_{ki}-\hat{\mu}_i\right)^2\] Note the factor \(\frac{1}{n}\) (not \(\frac{1}{n-1}\))
Data matrix notation:
The empirical mean and covariance can also be written in terms of the data matrix \(\symbfit X\).
If the data matrix \(\symbfit X\) follows the statistics convention we can write
\[\hat{\symbfit \mu} = \frac{1}{n} \symbfit X^T \symbfup 1_n\]
\[\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma} = \frac{1}{n} \symbfit X^T \symbfit X- \hat{\symbfit \mu} \hat{\symbfit \mu}^T\]
On the other hand, if \(\symbfit X\) follows the engineering convention with samples in columns the estimators are written as:
\[\hat{\symbfit \mu} = \frac{1}{n} \symbfit X\symbfup 1_n\]
\[\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma} = \frac{1}{n} \symbfit X\symbfit X^T - \hat{\symbfit \mu} \hat{\symbfit \mu}^T\]
To avoid confusion when using matrix or component notation you need to always state which convention is used! In these notes we exlusively follow the statistics convention.

title: 2  Multivariate estimation
text:
2.3 Maximum likelihood estimation

General principle
R.A. Fisher (1922) 2: model-based estimators using the density or probability mass function
Log-likelihood function:
Observing data \(D=\{ \symbfit x_1, \ldots, \symbfit x_n\}\) the log-likelihood function is
\[\log L(\symbfit \theta| D ) = \sum^{n}_{k=1}  \underbrace{\log f}_{\text{log-density}}(\symbfit x_k |\symbfit \theta)\]
Maximum likelihood estimate: \[\hat{\symbfit \theta}_{\text{ML}}=\underset{\symbfit \theta}{\arg\,\max} \log L(\symbfit \theta| D)\]
Maximum likelihood (ML) finds the parameters that make the observed data most likely (it does not find the most probable model!)
Recall from MATH27720 Statistics 2 that maximum likelihood is closely linked to minimising the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence \(D_{\text{KL}}(F, F_{\symbfit \theta})\) between the unknown true model \(F\) and the specified model \(F_{\symbfit \theta}\). Specifically, for large sample size \(n\) the model \(F_{\hat{\symbfit \theta}}\) fit by maximum likelihood is indeed the model that is closest to \(F\).
Correspondingly, the great appeal of maximum likelihood estimates (MLEs) is that they are optimal for large \(\mathbf{n}\), i.e. so that for large sample size no estimator can be constructed that outperforms the MLE (note the emphasis on “for large \(n\)”!). A further advantage of the method of maximum likelihood is that it does not only provide a point estimate but also the asymptotic error (via the observed Fisher information which is related to the curvature of the log-likelihood function).


Maximum likelihood estimates of the parameters of the multivariate normal distribution
We now derive the MLE of the parameters \(\symbfit \mu\) and \(\symbfit \Sigma\) of the multivariate normal distribution. The corresponding log-likelihood function is \[
\begin{split}
\log L(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma| D) & = \sum_{k=1}^n \log f( \symbfit x_k | \symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma) \\
  & = -\frac{n d}{2} \log(2\pi) -\frac{n}{2} \log \det(\symbfit \Sigma)  
   - \frac{1}{2}  \sum_{k=1}^n  (\symbfit x_k-\symbfit \mu)^T \symbfit \Sigma^{-1} (\symbfit x_k-\symbfit \mu) \,.\\
\end{split}
\] Written in terms of the precision matrix \(\symbfit \Omega= \symbfit \Sigma^{-1}\) this becomes \[
\log L(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Omega| D) = -\frac{n d}{2} \log(2\pi) +\frac{n}{2} \log \det(\symbfit \Omega)  - \frac{1}{2}  \sum_{k=1}^n  (\symbfit x_k-\symbfit \mu)^T \symbfit \Omega(\symbfit x_k-\symbfit \mu) \,.
\] First, to find the MLE for \(\symbfit \mu\) we compute the derivative with regard to the vector \(\symbfit \mu\) \[ \frac{\partial \log L(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Omega| D) }{\partial \symbfit \mu}= \sum_{k=1}^n  (\symbfit x_k-\symbfit \mu)^T \symbfit \Omega\] noting that \(\symbfit \Omega\) is symmetric. Setting this equal to zero we get \(\sum_{k=1}^n \symbfit x_k = n \hat{\symbfit \mu}_{ML}\) and thus \[\hat{\symbfit \mu}_{ML} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n \symbfit x_k\,.\]
Next, to obtain the MLE for \(\symbfit \Omega\) we compute the derivative with regard to the matrix \(\symbfit \Omega\) \[\frac{\partial \log L(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Omega| D) }{\partial \symbfit \Omega}=\frac{n}{2}\symbfit \Omega^{-1} - \frac{1}{2}  \sum_{k=1}^n (\symbfit x_k-\symbfit \mu) (\symbfit x_k-\symbfit \mu)^T\]. Setting this equal to zero and substituting the MLE for \(\symbfit \mu\) we get \[\widehat{\symbfit \Omega}^{-1}_{ML}=  \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n  (\symbfit x_k-\hat{\symbfit \mu}) (\symbfit x_k-\hat{\symbfit \mu})^T=\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML}\,.\]
See the supplementary Matrix Refresher notes for the relevant formulas in vector and matrix calculus.
Therefore, the MLEs are identical to the empirical estimates.
Note the factor \(\frac{1}{n}\) in the MLE of the covariance matrix.

section: 2.4 Sampling distribution of the empirical / maximum likelihood estimates
text:
2.4 Sampling distribution of the empirical / maximum likelihood estimates
With \(\symbfit x_1,...,\symbfit x_n \sim N_d(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma)\) one can find the exact distributions of the estimators. The sample average is denoted by \(\bar{\symbfit x}= \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \symbfit x_i\)
1. Distribution of the estimate of the mean:
The empirical estimate of the mean is normally distributed:
\[\hat{\symbfit \mu}_{ML}=\bar{\symbfit x} \sim N_d\left(\symbfit \mu, \frac{\symbfit \Sigma}{n}\right)\] Since \(\text{E}(\hat{\symbfit \mu}_{ML}) = \symbfit \mu\Longrightarrow \hat{\symbfit \mu}_{ML}\) is unbiased.
2. Distribution of the covariance estimate:
The empirical and unbiased estimate of the covariance matrix is Wishart distributed:
Case of unknown mean \(\symbfit \mu\) (estimated by \(\bar{\symbfit x}\)):
\[\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n (\symbfit x_i -\bar{\symbfit x})(\symbfit x_i -\bar{\symbfit x})^T \sim \text{W}_d\left(\frac{\symbfit \Sigma}{n}, n-1\right)\]
Since \(\text{E}(\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML}) = \frac{n-1}{n}\symbfit \Sigma\) \(\Longrightarrow \widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML}\) is biased, with \(\text{Bias}(\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML} ) = \symbfit \Sigma- \text{E}(\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML}) = -\frac{\symbfit \Sigma}{n}\).
Easy to make unbiased: \(\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{UB} = \frac{n}{n-1}\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML}=
\frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{k=1}\left(\symbfit x_k-\bar{\symbfit x}\right)\left(\symbfit x_k-\bar{\symbfit x}\right)^T\) which is distributed as \[\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{UB}  \sim \text{W}_d\left(\frac{\symbfit \Sigma}{n-1}, n-1\right)\]
Hence \(\text{E}(\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{UB}) = \symbfit \Sigma\) \(\Longrightarrow \widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{UB}\) is unbiased.
But unbiasedness of an estimator is not a very relevant criterion in multivariate statistics, especially when the number of samples is small compared to the dimension (see further below).
Covariance estimator for known mean \(\symbfit \mu\):
\[\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n (\symbfit x_i -\symbfit \mu)(\symbfit x_i -\symbfit \mu)^T \sim \text{W}_d\left(\frac{\symbfit \Sigma}{n}, n\right)\]

title: 2  Multivariate estimation
text:
2.5 Small sample estimation

Problems with maximum likelihood in small sample settings and high dimensions
Modern data is high dimensional!
Data sets with \(n<d\), i.e. high dimension \(d\) and small sample size \(n\) are now common in many fields, e.g., medicine, biology but also finance and business analytics.
\[n = 100 \, \text{(e.g, patients/samples)}\] \[d = 20000 \, \text{(e.g., genes/SNPs/proteins/variables)}\] Reasons:

the number of measured variables is increasing quickly with technological advances (e.g. genomics)
but the number of samples cannot be similary increased (for cost and ethical reasons)

General problems of MLEs:

ML estimators are optimal only if sample size is large compared to the number of parameters. However, this optimality is not any more valid if sample size is moderate or smaller than the number of parameters.
If there is not enough data the ML estimate overfits. This means ML fits the current data perfectly but the resulting model does not generalise well (i.e. model will perform poorly in prediction)
If there is a choice between different models with different complexity ML will always select the model with the largest number of parameters.

-> for high-dimensional data with small sample size maximum likelihood estimation does not work!!!
History of Statistics:






Figure 2.1: Very brief sketch of the statistics in the 20th and 21st century.



Much of modern statistics (from 1960 onwards) is devoted to the development of inference and estimation techniques that work with complex, high-dimensional data (cf. Figure 2.1).

Maximum likelihood is a method from classical statistics (time up to about 1960).
From 1960 modern (computational) statistics emerges, starting with “Stein Paradox” (1956): Charles Stein showed that in a multivariate setting ML estimators are dominated by (= are always worse than) shrinkage estimators!
For example, there is a shrinkage estimator for the mean that is better (in terms of MSE) than the average (which is the MLE)!

Modern statistics has developed many different (but related) methods for use in high-dimensional, small sample settings:

regularised estimators
shrinkage estimators
penalised maximum likelihood estimators
Bayesian estimators
Empirical Bayes estimators
KL / entropy-based estimators

Most of this is out of scope for our class, but will be covered in advanced statistical courses.
Next, we describe a simple regularised estimator for the estimation of the covariance that we will use later (i.e. in classification).


Estimation of covariance matrix in small sample settings
Problems with ML estimate of \(\symbfit \Sigma\)

\(\Sigma\) has O(\(d^2\)) number of parameters! \(\Longrightarrow \hat{\symbfit \Sigma}^{\text{MLE}}\) requires a lot of data! \(n\gg d \text{ or } d^2\)
if \(n < d\) then \(\hat{\symbfit \Sigma}\) is positive semi-definite (even if the true \(\Sigma\) is positive definite!)
\(\Longrightarrow \hat{\symbfit \Sigma}\) will have vanishing eigenvalues (some \(\lambda_i=0\)) and thus cannot be inverted and is singular!

Note that in many expression in multivariate statistics we actually need to use the inverse of the covariance matrix, e.g., in the density of the multivariate normal distribution, so it is essential that we obtain a non-singular invertible estimate of the covariance matrix.
Making the ML estimate of \(\symbfit \Sigma\) invertible
There is a simple numerical trick credited to A. N. Tikhonov to make \(\hat{\symbfit \Sigma}\) invertible, by adding a small number (say \(\varepsilon=10^{-6}\) to the diagonal elements of \(\hat{\symbfit \Sigma}\): \[
\symbfit S_{\text{Tik}} = \hat{\symbfit \Sigma} + \varepsilon \symbfit I
\]
The resulting \(\symbfit S_{\text{Tik}}\) is positive definite because the sum of a symmetric positive definite matrix (\(\varepsilon \symbfit I\)) and a symmetric positive semi-definite matrix (\(\hat{\symbfit \Sigma}\)) is always positive definite.
However, while this simple regularisation results in an invertible matrix the estimator itself has not improved over the MLE, and the matrix \(\symbfit S_{\text{Tik}}\) will also be poorly conditioned (i.e. large condition number).
Simple regularised estimate of \(\symbfit \Sigma\)
Regularised estimator \(\symbfit S^\ast\) = convex combination of \(\symbfit S= \hat{\symbfit \Sigma}^\text{MLE}\) and \(\symbfit I_d\) (identity matrix) to get
Regularisation: \[
\underbrace{\symbfit S^\ast}_{\text{regularised estimate}} = (1-\lambda)\underbrace{\symbfit S}_{\text{ML estimate}} +\underbrace{\lambda}_{\text{shrinkage intensity}} \, \underbrace{\symbfit I_d}_{\text{target}}\]
Idea: choose \(\lambda \in [0,1]\) such that \(\symbfit S^\ast\) is better (e.g. in terms of MSE) than both \(\symbfit S\) and \(\symbfit I_d\). Note that \(\lambda\) does not need to be small like \(\varepsilon\).
This form of estimator is corresponds to computing the mean of the Bayesian posterior by directly shrinking the MLE towards a prior mean (target): \[
\underbrace{\symbfit S^\ast}_{\text{posterior mean}} = \underbrace{\lambda \symbfit I_d}_{\text{prior information}}  + (1-\lambda)\underbrace{\symbfit S}_{\text{data summarised by maximum likelihood}}
\]

Prior information helps to infer \(\symbfit \Sigma\) even in small samples.
also called shrinkage estimator since the off-diagonal entries are shrunk towards zero.
this type of linear shrinkage/regularisation is natural for exponential family models (Diaconis and Ylvisaker, 1979).
Instead of a diagonal target other options are possible, e.g. block-diagonal or banded covariances.
If \(\lambda\) is not prespecified but learned from data (see below) then the resulting estimate is an empirical Bayes estimator.
The resulting estimate will typically be biased as mixing in the target will increase the bias.

How to find optimal shrinkage / regularisation parameter \(\lambda\)?






Figure 2.2: Bias-variance tradeoff to find optimal shrinkage intensity.



One way to do this is to chose \(\lambda\) to minimise \(\text{MSE}\) (Mean Squared Error) — see Figure 2.2. This is also called L2 regularisation or Ridge regularisation.
Bias-variance trade-off: \(\text{MSE}\) is composed of squared bias and variance.
\[\text{MSE}(\theta) = \text{E}((\hat{\theta}-\theta)^2) = \text{Bias}(\hat{\theta})^2 + \text{Var}(\hat{\theta})\] with \(\text{Bias}(\hat{\theta}) = \text{E}(\hat{\theta})-\theta\)
\(\symbfit S\): ML estimate, many parameters, low bias, high variance
\(\symbfit I_d\): “target”, no parameters, high bias, low variance
\(\Longrightarrow\) reduce high variance of \(\symbfit S\) by introducing a bit of bias through \(\symbfit I_d\)!
\(\Longrightarrow\) overall, \(\text{MSE}\) is decreased
Challenge: since we don’t know the true \(\symbfit \Sigma\) we cannot actually compute the \(\text{MSE}\) directly but have to estimate it! How is this done in practise?

by cross-validation (=resampling procedure)
by using some analytic approximation (e.g. Stein’s formula)

In Worksheet 3 the empirical estimator of covariance is compared with the regularised covariance estimator implemented in the R package “corpcor”. This uses a regularisation similar as above (but for the correlation rather than the covariance matrix) and it employs an analytic data-adaptive estimate of the shrinkage intensity \(\lambda\). This estimator is a variant of an empirical Bayes / James-Stein estimator (see MATH27720 Statistics 2).

title: 2  Multivariate estimation
text:
2.6 Full Bayesian multivariate modelling
See also the section about multivariate distributions in the Probability and Distribution refresher for details about the distributions used below.

Three main scenarios
As discussed in MATH27720 Statistics 2 there are three main Bayesian models in the univariate case that cover a large range of applications:

the beta-binomial model to estimate proportions
the normal-normal model to estimate means
the inverse gamma-normal model to estimate variances

Below we briefly sketch the extensions of these three elementary models to the multivariate case.


Dirichlet-multinomial model
This generalises the univariate beta-binomial model.
The Dirichlet distribution is useful as conjugate prior and posterior distribution for the parameters of a categorical distribution.

Data: \(D=\{\symbfit x_1, \ldots, \symbfit x_n\}\) with \(\symbfit x_i \sim \text{Cat}(\symbfit \pi)\)
MLE: \(\hat{\symbfit \pi}_{ML} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \symbfit x_i\)
Prior parameters (Dirichlet in mean parameterisation): \(k_0\), \(\symbfit \pi_0\),
\[\symbfit \pi\sim \text{Dir}(\symbfit \pi_0, k_0)\] \[\text{E}(\symbfit \pi) = \symbfit \pi_0\]
Posterior parameters: \(k_1 = k_0+n\), \(\symbfit \pi_1 = \lambda \symbfit \pi_0 + (1-\lambda) \, \hat{\symbfit \pi}_{ML}\) with \(\lambda = \frac{k_0}{k_1}\)
\[\symbfit \pi\,| \, D \sim \text{Dir}(\symbfit \pi_1, k_1)\] \[\text{E}(\symbfit \pi\,| \, D) = \symbfit \pi_1\]
Equivalent update rule (for Dirichlet with \(\symbfit \alpha\) parameter): \(\symbfit \alpha_0\) \(\rightarrow\) \(\symbfit \alpha_1 = \symbfit \alpha_0 + \sum_{i=1}^n \symbfit x_i = \symbfit \alpha_0 + n \hat{\symbfit \pi}_{ML}\)



Multivariate normal-normal model
This generalises the univariate normal-normal model.
The multivariate normal distribution is useful as conjugate prior and posterior distribution of the mean:

Data: \(D =\{\symbfit x_1, \ldots, \symbfit x_n\}\) with \(\symbfit x_i \sim N_d(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma)\) with known mean \(\symbfit \Sigma\)
MLE: \(\widehat{\symbfit \mu}_{ML} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n \symbfit x_i\)
Prior parameters: \(k_0\), \(\symbfit \mu_0\) \[\symbfit \mu\sim N_d\left(\symbfit \mu_0, \frac{\symbfit \Sigma}{k_0}\right)\] \[\text{E}(\symbfit \mu) = \symbfit \mu_0\]
Posterior parameters: \(k_1 = k_0+n\), \(\symbfit \mu_1 = \lambda \symbfit \mu_0 + (1-\lambda) \widehat{\symbfit \mu}_{ML}\) with \(\lambda = \frac{k_0}{k_1}\)
\[\symbfit \mu\, |\, D \sim N_d\left( \symbfit \mu_1, \frac{\symbfit \Sigma}{k_1}  \right)\] \[\text{E}(\symbfit \mu\, |\, D) = \symbfit \mu_1\]



Inverse Wishart-normal model
This generalises the univariate inverse gamma-normal model for the variance.
The inverse Wishart distribution is useful as conjugate prior and posterior distribution of the covariance:

Data: \(D =\{\symbfit x_1, \ldots, \symbfit x_n\}\) with \(\symbfit x_i \sim N_d(\symbfit \mu, \symbfit \Sigma)\) with known mean \(\symbfit \mu\)
MLE: \(\widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML} = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n (\symbfit x_i-\symbfit \mu)(\symbfit x_i-\symbfit \mu)^T\)
Prior parameters: \(\kappa_0\), \(\symbfit \Sigma_0\) \[\symbfit \Sigma\sim \text{W}^{-1}_d\left( \kappa_0 \symbfit \Sigma_0 \, , \,  \kappa_0+d+1\right)\] \[\text{E}(\symbfit \Sigma) = \symbfit \Sigma_0\]
Posterior parameters: \(\kappa_1 = \kappa_0+n\), \(\symbfit \Sigma_1 = \lambda \symbfit \Sigma_0 + (1-\lambda) \widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML}\) with \(\lambda = \frac{\kappa_0}{\kappa_1}\)
\[\symbfit \Sigma\, |\, D \sim \text{W}^{-1}_d\left( \kappa_1 \symbfit \Sigma_1 \, , \,  \kappa_1+d+1\right)\] \[\text{E}(\symbfit \Sigma\, |\, D) = \symbfit \Sigma_1\]
Equivalent update rule: \(\nu_0\) \(\rightarrow\) \(\nu_1 = \nu_0+n\), \(\symbfit \Psi_0\) \(\rightarrow\) \(\symbfit \Psi_1 = \symbfit \Psi_0 + \sum_{i=1}^n (\symbfit x_i-\symbfit \mu)(\symbfit x_i-\symbfit \mu)^T
= \symbfit \Psi_0 + n \widehat{\symbfit \Sigma}_{ML}\)

title: 2  Multivariate estimation
text:
2.7 Conclusion

Multivariate models are often high-dimensional with large number of parameters but often only a small number of samples are available. In this instance it is useful (and often necessary) to introduce additional information (via priors or by regularisation).
Unbiased estimation, a highly valued property in classical univariate statistics when sample size is large and number of parameters is small, is typically not a good idea in multivariate settings and often leads to poor estimators.
Regularisation introduces bias and reduces variance, minimising overall MSE. Likewise, Bayesian estimators also introduce bias and regularise (via the prior) and thus are useful in multivariate settings.
